in pencil  Whipple, Gregory [1956]
2336 - A McKinley Ave.
Berkely 3, Calif.
Oct. 30, 1956
Dear Jack: -

You had a right to expect something more in the way of thanks than my minimal 

pateerd? postcard?. Indeed, if I remember right, I said in it, "This, for the unrest?...,"
or something to that effect.

 Well, it's been a hell of a long unrest, and so I can only hope that you will not spurn this,

which, obviously enough, is intended to be what I am talking about.

 I haven't written sooner because I didn't finish reading "M.H." until late last night. Don't

laugh. It's about one page a day, and at the rate of about one word a minute. And this has it been
for a long time - in fact, ever since the  unbid?ner?  of that great intellectual ?.ge? in the
first grade. No kidding, it's a wonder

that I can write more than my own name.
 I wonder which of your selections made you laugh the most. In case you're curious about my own

reaction - it was "A  Hearthry Joins Alpha Cholerd?."  Convulsive.

 The days are getting wet and (for us) cold. Cavorting in FUNVILLE, U.S.A. (S.F. to you) will probably be

abated somewhat, therefore, lest the tissues fail to snap back as they usually do when the environment is 
more clement. Reading over here, on the other hand, will probably be compensatorily increased somewhat,
and if it is, I shall try to satisfy my curiosity about some of the works of yours mentioned in the dust jacket.
If local resources fail me, I shall ask for your help. But let it be clearly understood that I shall accept it only
if I am permitted to pay in full.

 Good luck to you. Hope to see you next summer. -  Gregory Whipple

letterhead
Red Clay reader
2221 Westminster Place Charlotte North Carolina 28207
Dear Jack Conroy,

 Thanks! for your letter and interest! Hope you can review RCR!
 Suppose you have your copy by now - and I did send one to Hope Norris!
  Things wild here!  will write soon
Charleen Whisnant   Editor

August 12, 1975
Dear Mr. Conroy,

 I've always intended to drop you a line, but something always comes up. I'm Dorothy Hopkin's son-in-law. 

Now that I've started this letter, I don't know what to say. Perhaps, something very literary. It just seemed that
since you were so close at hand - after a fashion - I shouldn't miss the chance to introduce myself.

 Usually, I read on lunch hour, but this book on writing suggests letters - lots of letters - to improve one's skills

in writing. Well anyway, I read awhile back in the Daily World that you were publishing a collection from the
Anvil. That's great! I haven't read it yet, but I intend to get a copy, whenever. Lydia, my wife, went through the
New Masses Anthology in one afternoon. It was some of the first fiction I've enjoyed since college.

 Funny thing, I used to read lots of fiction when I was in the service. My college English courses made novels and

short stories so uninteresting that I came out feeling that I was wasting valuable reading time whenever I read novels
or short stories.

 Well, that's something else.   We live in New Orleans. My wife

Note: letter not continued

Midwest Cultural Conference
P.O. Box 5224
Kansas City, Kansas 66119
Jack - Tom sent a card to say this "should start
some good fights!"

 Anon,   Fred

Dear Jack -

 The Tennessee screamer thought you would be interested in this stuff.

Actually Farrell seems pretty disappointing to me here - chiding others
for their lack of ideas without stating what his own are...

 Conference plans proceed apace - we'll be in touch -
    Best,   Fred

postcard  MRS. CARRY A. NATION was born in KENTUCKY as CARRY AMELIA MOORE.  She came to Medicine Lodge Kansas, as the wife of David Nation in the early nineties.  Her first husband, Dr. Charles Gloyd, had died a drunkard, leaving her with a little girl and a heart of sorrow.  She became very sympathetic with those who suffered as she, and began crusading against liquor in 1900.  She later lectured in all 48 States, Canada, England and Scotland.  She died June 9, 1911, at Leavenworth, Kansas and was buried in the family lot at Belton, Mo.
postmark  WICHITA KS 672  PM 3 unclear 1979
Dear Jack - Is she one of your heroines?!  After  visiting this place I got so thirsty I went across the street & got a six-pack of beer!
Best always, Fred Whitehead
Jack Conroy
701 Fisk
Moberly, MO.  65270

Veterans Day 1980
Dear Jack -

 Just a hasty note - Vance Randolph died November 1st in a Fayetteville hospital aetat. 88.

AVE ATQUG VALE! My visit with him & Mary, summer of 1979 was marvellous unforgettable
(only acting notice in K.C. Times - Nov. 3, 1980)

 And - a note from Foster from another old buddy of your'n. -
 Doug Wixson apparently is trying to arrange a get together in Moberly - between you & Wally Wharton -

but Harold & I will try to join in too -

 Leaving in A.M. for three-day  trip to the wilds of Western Kansas -
       Cheers,    Fred
                       ____
        Fred Whitehead

Dear Jackson -
 How could I resist? Hope this is of a quality to rank with the noted

illustrations discovered by the infamous Dr. Algren.

 Sylvia and I traveling north to get the auto-caret? in order. Then

back to Rome and the book. When things are in order I will get a good
letter off in answer to yours - which was wonderful. Hear about Ostroff?
Dr. says he'll be pop to twins!

 Ya. talg. sut.     Stan

Sig. Jack Conroy
6012 So. Green Street
Chicago, Illinois  U.S.A.

Widner, John
Star Orchard
Jacksonville, MO.
11/9/56
Mr. Jack Conroy
6012 South Green St.
Chicago 21, ILL.
Dear Jack: Glad you noticed my letter in the Guardian, and that you wrote me, many thanks
for your book "Midland Humor" I know I will enjoy it. No I do not see the American Socialist.

 I wish you would send me a copy of the A. Socialist also a copy of underline any /underline

other "Socialist" or left wing papers you have.

 If you do not have certain ones mabe [sic]  you could send me a list of their names and addresses.

I want to get in contact with them, to try to   (over)

2
work out some plan of uniting the "disinherited" into a Solid "left front party.
I have some Ideas I think can Win. and of course will not rest until I have tried them.

 I can see no real reason why all the "Socialists" should not united into one real

"Socialist" party. But we should not insist that it be named-labeled or called
Socialist - as many Liberal G.O.P. and progressive Democrats might come over
and support a "peoples" party or a "United Labor" party.

 Label is unimportant but unity on the left is all important. That now  p3

3
comes to the big ? how to get unity on the left? I believe all thinking people 
knows what they want. But we need to quit fighting between ourselves, Grant all
"Socialists" and others the same consideration we wish for ourselves.

 Now I have been a member of the Farmer-Labor and the progressive parties - But I

do not ask that any other leftists accept those labels

 We all no doubt would have better luck at unity and gaining members from the "Right" if

we chose an entirely new party name, I feel this could and should be decided at

4
a convention called later when we have the basis of unity lined up of the now existing
"Socialist" or splinter parties. for an example I would get in contact with others on the left
here in Missouri - to get a State Committee working to organize a "left" party on a
Statewide or local basis.

 With other Johns or Jacks doing somewhat likewise in other states and cities, Each local or

state group would report to a National Group or H'qtrs.

 So my part would be to get a State group together here in my own State, to furnish the

groundwork for building

5
a real peoples party in the State,  and of course the job of circulating petitions for enough Signatures
to put our party on the ballot here.

 This done in the various States will give us a united left wing party - of course our National Committee and

our National Canidates [sic], Etc. platform, Etc would come out of our National Conventions in a completely
democratic manner -

 Now to get a Wide participation in such a plan, let us start by

1. Contacting the 3 Socialist "Splinter"parties through the       on p6

6
"Socialist" papers and City dailys where we can get letters to "public opinon [sic]
to be printed.
2. Contacting direct with each other - without standing leaders on the left, with all
who may disagree with the "Wall Street Regime" Etc.

 I believe underline we will get /underline a dynamic response to our letters

to individuals and from our letters to Editors in the press.

 I believe the people are getting enough of a Corporation Regime headed by General

Motors Etc.      on p.7.

7

I believe "Adlai" could of won if he had of used the issues he had at hand.

He should of had a good Socialist to write his 'up'  his speeches, as it was
but a few could see any real difference in the Wall Street twins. What we
need is to give the voters a chance to vote for War or peace for high or Low
taxes for riot or reason.

 Now if you agree with me we are started on our way underline Now /underline

= You can count on me to do my part to get our party

8
on the ballot in MO.

Say when we get contacts organized in most all the states, that we call a

National convention, Etc we had better start now so we can have a party to
vote for in 1960.

 You can name me on to any National Committee we migh {sic] get together.
 You might get the needed help in Chicago from your present contacts. I suggest you

underline Call and See /underline a Mr. Albert Bofman 6327 South May
Chicago 21, ILL.   I am sure you can count on Mr. Bofman.

9.
it appears that one of our obsticals [sic] or hurdles to jump over to start with
is the internal disention [sic] withing [sic] the 3 Socialist parties.

 Surely there is enough common ground to stand on - underline such as our present

and future needs /underline, and the need for unity on the left.

 Lets stop all dividing foolishness as to wheather [sic] we like or dislike, Marx, Lenin,

or Stalin - They are all dead - lets unite for the needs of the living.

 Are you in any position to contact the 3 Socialist factions in the Chicago area?

10

If so, please do so, and let me know the results.  Lets Both write direct to
Darlington Hoopes.  Eric Haas and Farrell Dobbs.
 Four more years of Ike and Nixon should be more than enough to unite the left

if we have any leadership.   pardon the pencil as my typewriter is broken, will
get it fixed - also I have a Mimeograph. If you are this way anytime stop and we may swap a few.

 Always Glad to hear from you.
 Cooperatively;  John L. Widner   Jacksonville MO   "Allias" [sic] Adam Farmer

postcard
Series 200 - Huppler  Copyright 1948
SETTING HEN

Dear Jack: I hope the party was a great success but that you have enough strength left today

to total up the sales. I'd have come but that I had a long standing engagement for my nephew's
birthday. Wendell is still away, in Paris - seeing a lot of Alice B  - Don't look for him until
March but it is indefinite -     Best love -    Esther Wilcox

Dear Jack & all the rest, big & little.

I doubt you can be in a wider state of confusion than I am. One week going on

Country & state, the next being told I was far too rich, and all the while laboring
under the belief that I would run out before the money did, but now it looks as if
I wld [sic] live forever, blind deaf & dumb & unable to maintain my balance.
However I am back at work

in pencil Wilcox, Wendell B. [1978]

at theater. Pray I don't fall off my stool & lose control of baser functions during

working hours. And I will pray for you: just send lit list of locking functions.

 Love as always     Wendell

P.S. Have you heard of or from Fritz Leiber?

Season's Greeting printed in red

4.  
shared the log-covered shack with Hudson, who is my Ethan.  Once at a party meeting on the village green he chased two policemen all round the square and down Main Street to the sympathetic howls of the mill workers and chagrin of the cops.  Nights he'd play a yard long harmonica; God knows where he picked up such a monster.  He borrowed hens, set them, and returned the fowls keeping the chicks.  He had a hog in a woodland pen.  A man of gray hair he went on the Hunger March, came down with pneumonia, and now he writes me the doctor says he is dying.  I call it genius to be able to live happily on so little work.  Our cabin in the pines cost only twenty-three eighty to build.  Jack McCarthy, a carpenter on the Boston Elevated System sent us sliding car windows.  Even the stove we got out of a dump.  Hilda and I'd gladly live so again, only without my old friend, I fear we'd starve.  Nor could I cut ice and saw timber and maple sugar any more as I did among many tasks those two years.  I'm getting old myself; fifty now.

   I'll surely be glad to hear from you any time you feel so moved to write, and just as soon as the little book is bound, I'll send you a copy or two.

As ever,
Jack
P.S.  You  gave me a fine laugh in "there were a lot of fatheads around gumming up the works."  All the Comrade Davis, Comrade Brown, Comrade Lipservice "aides" I ever had in any work I ever did, no matter how hard I ever tried, made me a monkey on a jackass and turned our plans into burlesques which would have thrilled any police convention.  We were almost as laughable as the N.A. M and as self-ruinous.  We invariably muffed the ball.   Jack

8-2-77
Hi there Jack!

Thought you'd find these notes of some interest, especially since like you I'm now

returning to where I first heard the thunder roll down in South Carolina.

 I was in St. Louis for the recent NAACP confab and thought of you often when I'd

be passing "red square" about which you & I said we'd do some writing.

 Keep in touch with me: for I just might go back to St. Louis some day.
 All the best & love    Sidney

in pencil Williams, Thelma [no date]
Dear Jack Conroy: -

 Here is the chapter!
 Let me know what you think, sincerely, so that I can send your statement right along -

to this youngster.   She is just 19 this month - but if she has something I'm for encouraging her -
As she talked with me - her idea is to show - trailer camps as being almost human - and not
the traditional scenes of murder.

 Thanks so much     Thelma Williams

P.S. Have you read Chester Hume's latest book? I think it's underline awful /underline.
See if you feel it is underline Anti-Semetic! /underline  I do and I might be wrong

3727 S. Ellis Ave

Dear Conroy: Raymond Kresinsky, 401 Old Pedesal Building, Des Moines, Iowa
has 3 stories of mine. He can 'plant them all. Ask him for 1 or 2 if you care to. Use this card as a lever. 
I have several short short stories I'll send you later, as soon as they have been typed and gone over.
Best wishes to you & the New Anvil. I feel low today tho' the sun is shining - not in Spain tho'

december a magazine of the arts and opinion
Robert Wilson, Movies editor 729 N. Mclean Lincoln, ILL. 62656

Dec. 5, 1973

Dear Jack,

 The parties with you and your friends were among the best I've ever attended. The autographing

party, in particular, seemed like a model for that type of thing. I hope you sold copies of the book
beyond your fondest expectations.

 I was especially grateful for the Otis Ferguson anecdote, which I've sent to Ferguson's widow.

If and when the underline otis /underline

underline Ferguson Reader /underline ever gets published, perhaps we can get together for
a second coming of the Camarilla. It's been a hell of a job resurrecting Ferguson, but now that the
underline Anvil /underline has made it perhaps it's Ferguson's turn.

 I hope the return to Moberly wasn't too much of a downer. Drifting back to the pace [sic] of Lincoln

often gives me the bends after time spent in Chicago. But after twenty years in Chicago, I'm almost ready
to say it's a nice place to visit, etc.

 It was great meeting you and I hope our trails cross again.    Best, Bob Wilson

729 N. McLean
Lincoln, IL 62656
May 10, 1974
Dear Jack,

 I'd be delighted to become the sage of Lincoln. But as my father said of William Maxwell

when I asked him why Maxwell has not been honored as a writer in his hometown: (quote)
"He's been gone a long time." (unquote)  I also was gone a long time and I'm afraid no-one
knows, or cares, that I'm back.

 Another reason I can't become a sage, probably, is that I'm not smart enough. I not only was

not aware that a controversy existed over the position of the you-know-what of the Oriental
female, but now that you've ^ brought it to my attention I can only say that I'll be darned if I
understand the question underline or /underline the controversy.

 However, to compensate, I'll give you all the information I have on the anatomy of the Korean

female

(gathered, obviously, at first hand).

 First, the Korean female has little body hair (including the pubic area, which Korea no country for

hair fetishes). A Korean girl will never, never ever, have to shave her legs or under her arms or ever have to worry
about embarrassing facial hair.

 Second, due to the relatively bland diet of vegetables, fish, and rice - and the relative absence of meat, which is

expensive - she doesn't have to use deodorants. Sweat comes out as an odorless liquid. Koreans don't develop body
odors. the fetish for bathing comes from an abhorrence of dust and dirt - of which there's a lot blowing in the wind.

 Third, again due  to the diet, Korean girls more often than not have that in - and-out violin-shaped figure that sucks

in at the waist

-2-
and blossoms at the hips so coveted by American diet columns.

 Fourth, due to a relatively small rib cage, Korean girls have surprisingly voluptuous breasts which

you wouldn't guess when gazing at their dimensions when clothed.

 This has been a long way round my puzzlement at your question. But they do have you-know-what and I

suppose that's the same the world over.

 Best wishes, the Sage of Lincoln (hopefully)     Bob Wilson

Oct. 5
Dear Jack,

 Thanks very much for the card to Sue Young. I sent it on to her and I'm sure

she'll enjoy the purple rat.

 I've had some encouraging news on the underline Otis Ferguson Reader /underline.

The New Republic has started a New Republic  Book Company, and an editor there has asked to see the

manuscript. If the New Republic isn't interested in bringing old Otis back to life, the cause
may be hopeless. Southern Illinois turned the book down about three years ago, incidentally.

 Curt has gone thru another dark night of the soul. I called him a couple of weeks ago and

he sounded suicidal. He was sitting at home on

-2-
a workday burning holes in the mattress with a cigar. Periodically he got up to douse
the fire with a glass of water. (My writing is getting sloppy. I don't mean he was
underline intentionally /underline burning holes. But the fire on the mattress
was a recurrent theme in his conversation.) Anyway, his 2nd marriage is apparently
over. I talked to

him recently and he was feeling much better. He's taken an apartment on
Wellington around the area called New Town, along Broadway (a new hot
residential area in Chicago). Perhaps you'll hear from him more frequently
now that whatever marital problems were bedeviling him are again in the past.

 My book - barring

-3-
further disruptions in Curt's personal life - should be out in mid-November. My
last reviewer (John Denne in underline December - /underline 15) called me a
paranoid schizophrenic, so obviously I can take rough handling. If you review the book -
as I hope you're able to - please don't call me dull. Say anything, but not that. There's
an awful lot of material on

Chicago, incidentally, which hopefully will bring you back to the paying pages
of Panorama  or the Sun-Times. The whole last section of the book is on Chicago.

 Where did the ad for Jack Conroy at the Foolkiller appear? What city, that is. The

name of the city was trimmed off the page, which also included your review of
"The New Deal for Artists."

 I should have added earlier that underline December /underline has not

-4-
yet started back thru the typesetting mill after the fiasco of the bankrupt typesetter.
It's been over two years since December - 15 appeared. Curt seems to be trying
for 3 years. "The Hermaphrodite" is well inside the deadline, to say the least.

 Well, we're all obviously getting a little old and a little weary. Our readers

and fans will forgive us all, I'm sure.

 Best wishes,   Bob Wilson

in pencil [1975]
Sunday
Dear Jack,

 I thought you might enjoy this picture. You can add it to the front of the Ferguson book.
 Incidentally, if you know anyone on the U. of Missouri Press I'd appreciate your putting

in a good word sometime for the underline Otis Ferguson Reader /underline.
It's not as long as the film

book and is probably more representative of the variety of Ferguson's
work. It's been making the rounds of University presses without any
success. Malcolm Cowley will be 90 before he gets the opportunity to
write the introduction he's promised. oh well.

 I was very much struck by the differences between Moberly and Lincoln.

-2-
And by your picture of the coal mining neighborhood in "The Disinherited" as
contrasted with what I know of Depression conditions in North Lincoln.
Something saved Lincoln from the devastation you depict and I don't quite
know what it was. Certainly things were bleak among the families of children
I was friends with in North Lincoln. But

not as bad as "The Disinherited." I was also struck by the differences between my father
and you - approximately the same age, approximately from the same kind of background.
But everything else very different. I don't think anyone really understands the vagaries
of politics in the U.S. Certainly not Bob Wilson. I have never understood

-3-
my father's deep dislike of Roosevelt - much of it cloaked in small town
hyperbole but still bone-deep contempt for everything he stood for in the
Depression. The mysteries of politics pass over to the mysteries of personality.
I tend to cast a bemused eye on the passing political parade. Americans and their
devious passions

go beyond my understanding. which leaves me a lot of time for thinking
about movies.

 I'm sorry we didn't have time to visit the Monkey Nest area and the adjoining

cemetery. But you've probably done this tour so often you were relieved the
subject didn't come up.  Another time.

 I usually receive one-liners from Curt

-4-
when I hear at all - like "Nothing news." But I did relay your messages to him and also
said hello to Frank Nipp. Harlan Olafson acknowledges underline nothing /underline
not Christmas cards, not letters, not packages of books sent to him. I think his radicalism was
another one of those devious American passions, and that he's shed the skin

of December's political editor.

 I'll send you a copy of my book when it's ready - probably in November.

The last section - "Chicago" - contains some people you also know.

 You were a very gracious host - on no notice at all. Sue Young was pleased

to meet you - as were we all.    Best wishes,   Bob Wilson

card
be available in time for the New Year (hopefully).

 I'm happy to say that the 1974 issue of underlineDecember/underline

went to the typesetter Thanksgiving week. I assume that your memoir was included.

 Curt has split from his wife but still sleeps with her several nights a week. A most

modern arrangement.    Best,  Bob W.
printed  Season's Greetings  images of flowers

card printed
May all the joys of the holiday season be yours

 Dear Jack,
  December Press is experiencing a routine delay in producing

my book. underline But /underline Curt doth say, copies will

Sept. 25
Dear Jack,

 As always, it was very pleasant visiting you in Moberly. And I especially enjoyed

meeting Gladys for the first time.

 Curt swears that he's now settled down to a stretch of work getting out the issue of

underline December underline and

supplementary issues. (You might pitch him about doing the collection that
David Ray sabotaged. No royalties to speak of, but Curt turns out pretty good-
looking books.)

 Be well, keep writing.      Best wishes,     Bob Wilson

in pencil [1976?]

Thursday
Dear Jack,

 I've been hearing rumors of a Johnson-Nash trek to Moberly for several years now. Curt now threatens

to make it official by setting a date in May when he and Nash will be passing thru Lincoln on their way
to Moberly. Presumably, I can join the expedition if I choose to.

 I have a feeling that Curt's juices (interior and exterior) will be throbbing with the rites of Spring.

So I have some hesitation of going aboard as the sober, sane party who will see these two thru whatever dark nights
of the soul be in store. Also, I've never seen Nash in action outside safe confines of his haunts in Chicago.
Jay comes on very strong there as the last of the drinker-fighter gunslingers.  Which is OK. Except that even Mailer
would be carried feet first out of the average factory-workers saloon in Lincoln if he went into his famous boxer's
crouch. He might last one round but I doubt it.

-2-

 So, even if Jay and Curt carry thru on their threat to invade Moberly I'm not

sure that I'll enlist.

 If there's some reason why Mutt and Jeff (or the three Stooges, if I'm along)

should not do their Thunder Road bit into Moberly in May, you'd probably better
head Curt off at the pass right now. He sounds serious.

 underline Young in Illinois /underline, as expected died a quick death in the

public prints. No reviews anywhere, which is what I

expected. I suppose a scattering of reviews will appear in other little magazines. With
luck (No, that's not correct. There underline was /underline a short review planted in
a Boise, Idaho newspaper by a teacher - friend of mine. Out of sight, out of mind.)

 Lincoln is becoming a little too eerily like the 1930's all over again. For me, at least.

Reliving one's childhood at a comparatively advanced ate is a hell of a note.

 Sue Young send her regards, as do my parents.
   Best,    Bob Wilson

in pencil [1976?]

Nov. 1, 1977
Dear Jack,

 Curt tells me that you received an NEA writing grant.

Congratulations! I figured all along that you'd get one,
but you never know.

 underline December /underline as a magazine has faded from the

scene, but Curt has enough December

Press books lined up to keep him busy thru 1979.

 I read somewhere that a underline Jack Conroy Reader /underline is on

the way. Would the publisher be interested in an underline Otis Ferguson Reader? /underline
It's pathetic, but

that marvelous collection is still going begging.

 Stay well, and keep writing.

Best wishes,   Bob Wilson

card
July 10, 1981
Dear Jack,

 Curt informs me that he and Jay are planning to visit Moberly in the

next 2 or 3 weeks. Batten down the storm doors!

 If Curt gets off onto morbid subjects, he'll probably

upside down Special delivery just for you
image of cat, mouse, bird, mailbox

-2-
tell you about the siege of illness I've undergone the past 18 months. I escaped
from the hospital most recently in April and I fear to press my luck by joining the
Rover Boys on their death-defying plunge thru Illinois and Missouri.  Next time.

 My mother and I were

-3-
delighted by your vigorous presence on the PBS documentary devoted
to the WPA arts program. I don't know whether the special has been shown
yet in the Chicago area, but I've alerted my daughter Sue Young to keep
an eye peeled for it. I thought the whole show was very well done. Sad about
all those paintings being obliterated by local boobs.

 underline At last, /underline the otis Ferguson Reader will be

-4-
published early next year. December Press has come to the rescue once again. I hope
that Curt makes a little money on the book, but past experience says that he won't.

 How's your autobiography coming along? I would guess that it should be nearing

completion by this time.

 Watch out for the terrible duo.    My very best to Gladys.
Best always,   Bob

in pencil on side Wilson, Bob [1981] - July

5-21-66
Dear Mr. Conroy,

 I meant to write this letter to you much sooner than this, in fact I was going

to write to you the same afternoon that I read your article in the Chicago Daily News.
The article concerned the late Willard Motley. I don't know if anybody wrote to you
about this article, but I did want to write and let you know that I thought it was a
marvelous and warm tribute to a man that I thought of and honored more than any
human being that I have ever known. I never got to meet Mr. Motley, but by reading
of, and about, him, I can tell that he must have been a wonderful human being. Numerous
times I have walked the streets and visited the places that he wrote about in his books, and
always thought about him when doing so. I thought of and admired this man so very, very, much -

more than words can say.

 I have, in the past year, put a notebook together containing just about everything

that has been printed by, and about, Willard Motley. These things I will cherish forever. 
Included in the collection is your fine article about him. Also, there are other pieces
written by Nelson Algren, Hoke Norris, Bob Ellison, and Herman Kogan. Also
included are pictures of him, articles from Chicago newspapers, articles from Rogue
magazine, newspaper clippings of his death, and I even have two articles written by
him for Commonweal Magazine dating back to 1939, which I sent for.

 Also included is a warm, friendly letter that was written to me by Willard's sister, 

Mrs. Flossie Moore. This letter answered my letter that I had written to her about a year ago. 
In the letter, she wrote and invited me to come to her home and visit

with her. I will probably be going to Chicago in June and I am looking forward
to visiting with Mrs. Moore.

 Well, I will close for now. I just wanted to write and let you know how much I

enjoyed your article on Willard Motley.

 If I may, I would like to ask a favor of you. If there is anything at all written about

Willard in the future, I would appreciate it very much if you would write me and inform
me of it. If you would do this it would make me very happy. Also, if you would know where
I might purchase a recent photo of him, this would also be kindly appreciated.

 Thank you so very much, Mr. Conroy. I hope that I will be hearing from you.
   Sincerely yours,    Frank Wingate Jr.

April 19, 1967
Dear Jack & Gladys,

 Thank you so very much for the card you sent. I'm glad to hear that you are

pleased that we have named our first son after Willard. He is a wonderful baby and
wish that Willard were still alive to see it. I cannot come all the way to Missouri to
show you the boy, but will do the next best thing and send you a photo of him.

 I have written twice to Flossie without an answer, but I have found out now that

her and Sammy are in California, so she has not received my letters. They sent me
a postcard saying that they would be returning

to Chicago soon, but gave no specific time. I hope when they return that they will be
pleased that I have named our boy after Willard.

 Congratulations to you and Arna Bontemps for winning the award. I am sure that you

feel proud and that you are appreciated. Will be looking for your paperback at local
bookstore. I would be very honored to be able to meet Arna someday.

 Well, I will be closing for now. Thanks again. Feel free to write anytime. Your letters

are always appreciated.            Your Friend.  Frank

Dear Jack -

 Glad to hear from you. Great to hear about the Diaries of Willard,

and looking forward to Jack Conroy Reader... Finished reading
underline The /underline Disinherited again.

 I enjoyed your review of Willard, but was disappointed in Nelson

Algren's review. I still admire Nelson and enjoyed article on him in
Chicago Style.

 Seen "Studs Lonigan" on T.V. I wish someday they would put

something on that does credit to a great book -

 Best of Luck    As Always - Your Friend and Admirer
    Frank Wingate
